# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
New-FileCatalog -CatalogVersion 2.0 -CatalogFilePath c:\test.cat -Path c:\test
```
open c:\test.cat in file explorer look at general tab

# Expected behavior

```powershell
New-FileCatalog -CatalogVersion 2.0 -CatalogFilePath c:\test.cat -Path c:\test
```
open c:\test.cat in file explorer and it shows v2 with a stronger algorithm

# Actual behavior

```powershell
New-FileCatalog -CatalogVersion 2.0 -CatalogFilePath c:\test.cat -Path c:\test
```
open c:\test.cat in file explorer and it shows v1 with a sha1 algorithm

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: Just tried this.  Even though when you specify `2.0` (or even just `2`), it is a version 2 catalog.  When you open the .cat file, it does show `Version=1` but that's `PublicVersion` which is always 1.  It also shows the algorithm as SHA-1, but if you inspect the individual file hashes, it shows ash SHA-256.  I see the same behavior with makecat.exe.  One small improvement we can make is a validate set for CatalogVersion since it only allows 1 or 2.  I can make this small change (PR https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/8368)

title: New-FileCatalog -CatalogVersion 2.0 creates a 1.0 cat file
